name: NPR
text:
The Biden campaign admits that one of its most effective weapons against President Trump is Trump himself.

"When your opponent is destroying himself, don't interrupt," agrees one Democratic strategist. https://t.co/6SQDAXr6ap

name: NPR
text: As tributes pour in for John Lewis, so do proposals for ways to honor the legacy of the long-time congressman and civil rights icon, who died at age 80 on Friday. https://t.co/ynZoSaD0tE

name: NPR
text: Are you "doomscrolling" right now? Click here to read why it’s addicting and how and why to stop. Or better yet, just turn off your device and get a good night's rest right now. https://t.co/sqo6Q7lwnW

name: NPR
text:
Last week, ICE agreed to allow international students to stay in the U.S. even if their schools opted for online-only learning this fall.

But U.S. consulate offices — where visa applicants are interviewed — are closed. And it's unclear when they'll open.
 https://t.co/fVKQEWZWK8

name: NPR
text: "Blacktop Wasteland" is a novel about stealing diamonds and driving away. But it's also about race, family, risking everything for others — and trying to be the father you wish your father had been, our reviewer says. https://t.co/kFSzSdnxGq

name: NPR
text:
Harry Gruyaert's new photography book "Edges" captures the places where humans interact with our world's natural borders: bodies of water. He's documented this for 44 years — unintentionally.

"I had so many pictures of seasides and didn't even know."
https://t.co/BCWFl1omKK

name: NPR
text:
In a lifetime of difficult fights — a battle with addiction, a lengthy pro boxing career, an unusual mission in Iraq — Termite Watkins says COVID-19 was his toughest battle yet. @OnlyAGameNPR
https://t.co/Pi0LyAZ4t0

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: @nprscottsimon tells the story of Manny's — a family-run deli in Chicago that's been struggling during the pandemic.
https://t.co/tcywx1YiYf

name: NPR
text:
Rina Sawayama spoke to NPR about releasing her debut album later than the industry standard, skewering racist tropes against Asian women in her music videos and going from a Cambridge student to a rising pop star.
 https://t.co/rR0IObJPUr

name: NPR
text:
A gunman dressed as a FedEx driver reportedly entered the North Brunswick home of U.S. District Court Judge Esther Salas on Sunday, fatally shooting her 20-year-old son and critically wounding her husband.
https://t.co/dRVKMfs9nG

name: NPR
text:
Coronavirus cases are rising in 49 places across the U.S., an NPR analysis shows.

Here's how much cases are up compared to 2 weeks ago:

📈 Puerto Rico: +231%
📈 Kentucky: +231%
📈 Montana: +122%
📈 North Dakota: +113%
📈 Missouri: +87%
https://t.co/JyBzIr88N6

name: NPR
text:
The first gene therapy for hemophilia could be approved by the FDA within six months, raising hopes for patients and their families.

But the treatment could cost as much as $3 million per patient—which would make it the most expensive drug ever approved.
https://t.co/MMXqiGW375

name: NPR
text:
Black people are more overrepresented among D.C.’s coronavirus deaths than America’s other largest cities. 

And compared to other cities with large Black populations and historic health disparities, its pandemic response was slow and passive. @apmreports
https://t.co/3fvX2OwSyc

name: NPR
text:
As Congress returns from recess, Nancy Pelosi and Mitch McConnell remain very far apart in what should be included in another coronavirus relief bill.

Here are 5 sticking points — including unemployment benefits and direct payments.
https://t.co/S9f5KipOOJ

name: NPR
text:
People who lose their job-based health plan usually get 60 days to decide to continue it under federal rules.

But under a recent change, the 60 days doesn't start until after the COVID-19 national emergency is declared to be at an end.
https://t.co/CMsLW8VbK8

name: NPR
text:
The most controversial stock on Wall Street could be about to go mainstream.

If Tesla reports another quarterly profit this week — as is widely expected — it will have cleared the last big hurdle for entering into the S&P 500.
https://t.co/t7z8oWWfKt

name: NPR
text:
Rwanda, with a population of 12 million, has recorded just over 1,500 coronavirus cases since reporting its first infection in mid-March.

Ohio has a similar population size — and has recently been reporting about 1,200 cases a day.
https://t.co/dEhqy4Rjix

name: NPR
text:
A number of prominent NFL players went to social media Sunday to voice concerns about the league's coronavirus safety protocols. The move comes as some players begin reporting to training camp this week.
https://t.co/z8tvB8dMb6

name: NPR
text:
Studies show children have lower rates of COVID-19 and have milder symptoms than adults. But there's less information on how much kids spread the virus — which is key to safely reopening schools.
https://t.co/n1uVcB6Xev

name: NPR
text:
GOP congressional leaders are pushing for a $1 trillion coronavirus relief bill — and a "technical fix" so that workers don't make more in unemployment benefits than they would otherwise make on the job. 
https://t.co/hzsOWhH89j

name: NPR
text:
In the late 1950s, the word "plantation" was used as a marketing tool to lure white residents to new developments in South Carolina. Now, there's a growing push to change the names of those properties.
https://t.co/HSgiVJ7jsv

name: NPR
text:
Trader Joe's is getting rid of product names such as Trader José's and Trader Ming's after an online petition demanded that the company "remove racist branding and packaging from its stores.”
https://t.co/TS0FkTVrIW

name: NPR
text: Georgia Democratic Party officials voted overwhelmingly for State Sen. Nikema Williams to succeed the late Rep. John Lewis, who represented the state's 5th congressional district since 1987. https://t.co/ymKyojABhW

name: NPR
text:
An experimental coronavirus vaccine from Oxford University and AstraZeneca triggered an immune response in more than 1,000 people without severe side effects, according to a new study. 
https://t.co/XBuPJRZKy2

name: NPR
text:
The FBI identified Roy Den Hollander, an "anti-feminist lawyer," as the suspected gunman who attacked the home of Judge Esther Salas, killing her son.

Den Hollander filed suits alleging that women get special treatment in violation of the Constitution.
https://t.co/lTmNVsfwT7

name: NPR
text:
Texas has had 10,000 new coronavirus cases a day on average over the last week.

“We thought that we were immune in Texas [early on,]” says one doctor. “But it came over and it came over hard, like a tsunami.”
https://t.co/TXnDAsnKTh

name: NPR
text:
New York City now says there were 13 confirmed COVID-19 deaths on July 11 — the 24-hour period in which Mayor Bill de Blasio had said there were no deaths reported from the disease.
https://t.co/lyF7bcPI1m

name: NPR
text:
Jacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams says police are not currently able to provide security for the Republican National Convention, citing poor planning and a lack of funding for the last-minute event.
https://t.co/oPcOoiCePS

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden spoke to a notable Muslim American advocacy organization Monday — a move that was rather historic for Muslim leaders, who can't recall another presidential nominee speaking directly to such a large group of Muslims.
https://t.co/Hah34QTTM9

name: NPR
text:
Florida’s biggest teacher's union, along with parents, have sued the state over its plans to reopen schools with in-person instruction.

They say the plan is a violation of Florida's constitution, which requires schools to operate safely.
https://t.co/TXNU04qKgG
